text:
Hey all - am aware that this definitely could have been discussed before, or it may be better off in a different location, so please let me know if it has.
I understand that BSP is calculated at start - i.e when the event actually becomes in-play, however, if i wanted to get the value that was as close to this as possible, before it is actually calculated, would i use the "SP_AVAILABLE" odds call & grab the "nearPrice" field? Or is it more complex than this because the lay-side odds are taken into account before calculating final BSP.

elements.text:
Hey all - am aware that this definitely could have been discussed before, or it may be better off in a different location, so please let me know if it has.
I understand that BSP is calculated at start - i.e when the event actually becomes in-play, however, if i wanted to get the value that was as close to this as possible, before it is actually calculated, would i use the "SP_AVAILABLE" odds call & grab the "nearPrice" field? Or is it more complex than this because the lay-side odds are taken into account before calculating final BSP.

text: Does anyone know the reason that the API only gives date-time values to a resolution of 1 second for things like placed date, matched data, settled date etc. ? I seem to only be able to get 1 second resolution be it an order stream or using listClearedOrders/listCurrentOrders.

elements.text: Does anyone know the reason that the API only gives date-time values to a resolution of 1 second for things like placed date, matched data, settled date etc. ? I seem to only be able to get 1 second resolution be it an order stream or using listClearedOrders/listCurrentOrders.

text: it is. NearPrice is the bsp if the market was to start at that very moment, however i think near price is not calculated with every update, which probs makes it rather unreliable. There are documentations on how bsp is calculated, you could try and calculate it yourself, however i m not sure if its possible due to bets that are placed as a limit order but have persistance type == MarketOnClose, i dont think you can distinct them from bets without that persistant type. I guess theoretically you could reverse engineer  those bets when you get a new nearPrice and from there on calculate the bsp on your own until the next nearPrice shows up ? :smile:

elements.text: it is. NearPrice is the bsp if the market was to start at that very moment, however i think near price is not calculated with every update, which probs makes it rather unreliable. There are documentations on how bsp is calculated, you could try and calculate it yourself, however i m not sure if its possible due to bets that are placed as a limit order but have persistance type == MarketOnClose, i dont think you can distinct them from bets without that persistant type. I guess theoretically you could reverse engineer  those bets when you get a new nearPrice and from there on calculate the bsp on your own until the next nearPrice shows up ?

text: Thanks <@UBS7QANF3>. I suppose we can get slightly more accurate placed/matched time estimates off the stream inferred at point of receipt and cancellation times would be the same on receipt of cancelOrders response. On the topic of the stream API, I have heard many times on here that the matching engine only matches bets every 50 milliseconds. Is this "inside" info or is it documented somewhere. Does this essentially mean that orders received after the last run by the matching engine are queued up in order until the next run, after which we get a traded volume update on the stream? So theoretically we can't get updates more than once every 50ms (per market)? But new amounts in the queue will be pushed as and when they appear, or are they subject to some similar minimum update interval?

elements.text: Thanks

. I suppose we can get slightly more accurate placed/matched time estimates off the stream inferred at point of receipt and cancellation times would be the same on receipt of cancelOrders response. On the topic of the stream API, I have heard many times on here that the matching engine only matches bets every 50 milliseconds. Is this "inside" info or is it documented somewhere. Does this essentially mean that orders received after the last run by the matching engine are queued up in order until the next run, after which we get a traded volume update on the stream? So theoretically we can't get updates more than once every 50ms (per market)? But new amounts in the queue will be pushed as and when they appear, or are they subject to some similar minimum update interval?

text: Yes queued up, yes you can't get updates more than every 50ms. The bets aren't live in the market until the matcher runs so no you don't see what is in the queue as it appears

elements.text: Yes queued up, yes you can't get updates more than every 50ms. The bets aren't live in the market until the matcher runs so no you don't see what is in the queue as it appears

text: Thanks. So when you place a bet, if you get a successful match in your placeOrders response, your money never actually is detectable in the money available queue? And essentially, you can treat receipts of traded volume amounts off the stream as a 50 millisecond candlestick chart?

elements.text: Thanks. So when you place a bet, if you get a successful match in your placeOrders response, your money never actually is detectable in the money available queue? And essentially, you can treat receipts of traded volume amounts off the stream as a 50 millisecond candlestick chart?

text: And essentially, ATL and ATB are only updated at the same interval with the XM adjusted amounts added 150 millisecs later

elements.text: And essentially, ATL and ATB are only updated at the same interval with the XM adjusted amounts added 150 millisecs later

text:
I don't think the 50ms is forbidden knowledge but it's probably one of those things buried deep in the API documentation. What I have more easily found is that, indirectly, we have:

• Virtual prices are updated 150ms after the non-virtual stream: <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/Exchange+Stream+API#ExchangeStreamAPI-Marketdatafieldfiltering/MarketDataFilter> - i.e. they are on a 200ms cycle
• listMarketBook is not supposed to be called more than 5 times a second: <https://docs.developer.betfair.com/display/1smk3cen4v3lu3yomq5qye0ni/listMarketBook> - because there won't be (virtual) updates more frequently than this

elements.text: I don't think the 50ms is forbidden knowledge but it's probably one of those things buried deep in the API documentation. What I have more easily found is that, indirectly, we have:
Virtual prices are updated 150ms after the non-virtual stream:
- i.e. they are on a 200ms cycle
listMarketBook is not supposed to be called more than 5 times a second:
- because there won't be (virtual) updates more frequently than this

text: Yes if your bet is fully matched in the matching cycle where it goes live then the relevant atl/atb field won't be updated just trd

elements.text: Yes if your bet is fully matched in the matching cycle where it goes live then the relevant atl/atb field won't be updated just trd

text: Ah ok right. I thought that the virtual prices were updated 150ms after EACH nonvirtual update, so it was like a lag of 150ms rather than a full virtual price application every 150ms

elements.text: Ah ok right. I thought that the virtual prices were updated 150ms after EACH nonvirtual update, so it was like a lag of 150ms rather than a full virtual price application every 150ms

text: So I'm getting ready to turn on some new strategies with new code and such, and I was thinking of trying to limit how liquid my account funds are in case there are problems while I turn it on small. I was thinking for the next couple weeks while I'm testing it out, I could manually just go into a futures market that's far away, like next EPL season or NFL super bowl winner or whatnot, and make a big offer at 1.01 that would never be matched, where the market won't have a reason to change for like 12 months, and thus lower my account's liquidity so the automation can't do anything too nuts. Is this something that people do? Are there some downsides to this that I'm not thinking of? Do y'all do something similar or another trick for the same outcome when you are doing a ton of changes?

text:
Hi - hope this is the right place to ask. Don't want to fill up the chat with my newbie questions. I have an active login with BFLW as per:
`trading.session_expired`
```False```
But when I run the example Flumine strategy as per:
`framework.run()`
```LoginError: API login: CERT_AUTH_REQUIRED```
That's the error I get. Is there a separate login class or function I'm not aware of? I'm using this for my credentials:
`trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient(username=user.name,`
                                       `password=user.password,`
                                       `app_key=user.key,`
                                       `certs=user.certs)`

`client = clients.BetfairClient(trading)`
`framework = Flumine(client=client)`
Which logs me in fine but not with Flumine. I am only using the demo API not the paid one so that's maybe affecting it since the Flumine example is trying to place a bet but the demo API doesn't have that functionality.
Thoughts?
TIA!
